text: Potential for pharmacokinetic interactions between Schisandra sphenanthera and bosutinib, but not imatinib: in vitro metabolism study combined with a physiologically‚Äêbased pharmacokinetic modelling approach Jeffry Adiwidjaja, 1 Alan V. Boddy, 2 , 3 and Andrew J. McLachlancorresponding author 1 Author information Article notes Copyright and License information PMC Disclaimer Associated Data  Supplementary Materials  Data Availability Statement  Go to: Abstract Aims  This study aimed to investigate the potential interaction between Schisandra sphenanthera, imatinib and bosutinib combining in vitro and in silico methods.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug
Study
Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: Methods  In vitro metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib using recombinant enzymes and human liver microsomes were investigated in the presence and absence of Schisandra lignans.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: Physiologically‚Äêbased pharmacokinetic (PBPK) models for the lignans accounting for reversible and mechanism‚Äêbased inhibitions and induction of CYP3A enzymes were built in the Simcyp Simulator (version 17) and evaluated for their capability to predict interactions with midazolam and tacrolimus.
label: Parameter
Drug
Drug

text: Their potential effect on systemic exposures of imatinib and bosutinib were predicted using PBPK in silico simulations.
label: Drug
Drug

text: Results  Schisantherin A and schisandrol B, but not schisandrin A, potently inhibited CYP3A4‚Äêmediated metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Target
Parameter
Drug
Drug

text: All three compounds showed a strong reversible inhibition on CYP2C8 enzyme with k i of less than 0.5 Œºmol L‚àí1.
label: Target
Parameter
Amount

text: The verified PBPK models were able to describe the increase in systemic exposure of midazolam and tacrolimus due to co‚Äêadministration of S. sphenanthera, consistent with the reported changes in the corresponding clinical interaction study (AUC ratio of 2.0 vs 2.1 and 2.4 vs 2.1, respectively).
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name
Study
Parameter
Amount
Amount
Amount
Amount

text: The PBPK simulation predicted that at recommended dosing regimens of S. sphenanthera, co‚Äêadministration would result in an increase in bosutinib exposure (AUC ratio 3.0) but not in imatinib exposure.
label: Herb name
Drug
Parameter
Amount
Drug

text: Conclusion  PBPK models for Schisandra lignans were successfully developed.
label: Herb name

text: Interaction between imatinib and Schisandra lignans was unlikely to be of clinical importance.
label: Drug
Herb name

text: Conversely, S. sphenanthera at a clinically‚Äêrelevant dose results in a predicted three‚Äêfold increase in bosutinib systemic exposure.
label: Herb name
Drug

text: Keywords: drug metabolism, herb‚Äìdrug interactions, modelling and simulation, physiologically‚Äêbased pharmacokinetic (PBPK) What is already known about this subject      Physiologically‚Äêbased pharmacokinetic (PBPK) modelling approaches combined with in vitro to in vivo extrapolation techniques have been extensively used for predicting clinically meaningful pharmacokinetic drug interactions.
label: Study

text: Schisandrin A, schisantherin A and schisandrol B, the major bioactive lignans in Schisandra sphenanthera are potent CYP3A modulators with evidence for clinically‚Äêsignificant drug interactions.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Parameter

text: What this study adds      PBPK models for the perpetrator compounds in S. sphenanthera were developed with a capability to predict the interactions of Schisandra constituents with midazolam and tacrolimus.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: Schisandra lignans at clinically‚Äêrelevant concentrations were predicted to have little to no effect on imatinib pharmacokinetics but were expected to lead to a three‚Äêfold increase in the systemic exposure of bosutinib.
label: Herb name
Parameter
Drug
Parameter
Drug

text: Go to: 1.

INTRODUCTION  Schisandra sphenanthera has long been an integral part of traditional Chinese medicine, while other closely‚Äêrelated species, Schisandra chinensis can be found in many Western countries.
label: Herb name
Ethnic group
Herb name

text: 1 These natural products (typically administered as dried ethanol extracts) are used mainly for their putative hepatoprotective effect 2 , 3 , 4 and have been explored for anti‚Äêcancer properties.
label: Extraction process
Pathology
Pathology

text: 5 , 6 Interestingly, S. sphenanthera alleviated tacrolimus‚Äêinduced diarrhoea in liver transplant recipients, although the underlying mechanism is not clear yet.
label: Herb name
Drug
Pathology

text: 4 Several biologically‚Äêactive dibenzocyclooctadiene lignans, namely schisantherin A, schisandrin A and schisandrol B (Table 1) have been identified in S. sphenanthera extract with evidence for cytochrome P450 (CYP)3A modulations.

text: 15  Clinically‚Äêimportant herb‚Äìdrug interactions with Schisandra lignans as the perpetrators have been reported for midazolam, 16 sirolimus 17 and tacrolimus.
label: Herb name

text: 4 , 18 , 19 Administration of S. sphenanthera extract (equivalent to 14, 19 and 1 mg day‚àí1 of schisandrin A, schisantherin A and schisandrol B, respectively) in Chinese transplant recipients expressing CYP3A5 enzyme reduced by 40% the tacrolimus dose required to achieve the predefined target of trough blood concentrations 19 and thus was more cost‚Äêeffective.
label: Herb name

Amount

text: 20 This has led to the investigation of S. sphenanthera as a promising pharmacokinetic enhancer (booster) to increase the bioavailability of CYP3A substrates.
label: Herb name
Parameter

text: 19 Conversely, there is also a potential for unwanted herb‚Äìdrug interactions with S. sphenanthera, e.g.
label: Herb name

text: a higher risk for exposure‚Äêrelated adverse events of the victim drugs.
label: Pathology

text: However, it is not possible to cover all the various permutations of combinations between natural products and conventional medicines by conducting dedicated clinical interaction studies.
label: Study

text: 21 Clearly, a reliable and systematic approach to predict these herb‚Äìdrug interactions is needed.
As for drug‚Äìdrug interactions, physiologically‚Äêbased pharmacokinetic (PBPK) modelling and simulation has been advocated for quantitative prediction of drug interactions with natural products.
22 Nevertheless, PBPK prediction of herb‚Äìdrug interactions is more challenging than that with conventional perpetrator drugs.

23 Prior knowledge of perpetrator compounds in a complex mixture (extract) and their typical maintenance dosing regimens are necessary for an accurate in vitro to in vivo extrapolation of herb‚Äìdrug interactions or lack thereof.
There is also a possibility for interactions among compounds in the extract which may alter their systemic exposure.
Hence, well‚Äêcharacterised natural products are essential for implementing this quantitative framework.

PBPK modelling has been successfully implemented in describing a number of potential herb‚Äìdrug interactions, including grapefruit juice with midazolam and simvastatin, 24 milk thistle with midazolam, warfarin 23 and raloxifene, 25 and St John's wort with a range of CYP substrates.
label: Herb name

text: 26  Imatinib and bosutinib are both approved as the first‚Äêline treatments for Philadelphia chromosome‚Äêpositive (Ph+) chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML).
label: Drug
Drug
Pathology

text: 27 , 28 , 29 People with CML and receiving treatment with tyrosine kinase inhibitors are known to concomitantly use complementary medicines, 30 including S. sphenanthera, with a purported aim to help manage adverse effects.
label: Pathology
Target
Drug
Herb name
Pathology

text: The common side effects for patients being treated with these kinase inhibitors are gastrointestinal disturbances, e.g.
label: Pathology
Target
Drug
Pathology

text: diarrhoea, 28 , 31 while elevation of alanine transaminase is more frequent for bosutinib.
label: Pathology
Parameter
Drug

text: 28 S. sphenanthera may be beneficial for ameliorating these adverse events, 3 , 4 in addition to its potential anti‚Äêcancer activity.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Pathology

text: 5 , 6 Imatinib and bosutinib have distinct pharmacokinetic characteristics.
label: Drug
Drug

text: Imatinib is a substrate for both CYP3A4 and CYP2C8 enzymes and has a low hepatic extraction ratio (EH), 32 while bosutinib is a high EH drug almost exclusively metabolised by CYP3A4.
label: Drug
Parameter
Parameter
Parameter
Drug
Parameter
Parameter

text: 33 Therefore, both medicines are prone to CYP3A modulation by S. sphenanthera.
label: Parameter
Herb name

text: The development and evaluation of PBPK models for the Schisandra lignans will provide a greater understanding and allow the prediction of interactions with both drugs.
label: Herb name

text: The aim of this study was to build, evaluate and implement PBPK models of key perpetrator compounds found in S. sphenanthera extract for investigating the potential herb‚Äìdrug interactions with imatinib and bosutinib.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

METHODS 2.1.
Inhibition of in vitro metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib by Schisandra lignans 2.1.1.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: Materials  Imatinib (mesylate salt), bosutinib, schisandrin A, schisantherin A, schisandrol B, Œ≤‚Äênicotinamide adenine dinucleotide 2‚Ä≤‚Äêphosphate reduced (NADPH) tetrasodium salt, azamulin, dipotassium hydrogen phosphate trihydrate, potassium dihydrogen phosphate, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and pooled human liver microsomes (M0317) were purchased from Sigma‚ÄêAldrich (Castle Hill, NSW, Australia).

text: N‚Äêdesmethyl imatinib was obtained from Toronto Research Chemicals (North York, ON, Canada).
label: Drug

text: Recombinant CYP3A4 enzyme were procured from Corning (Woburn, MA; distributed by In Vitro Technologies, Noble Park, VIC, Australia).
label: Parameter

text: In vitro inhibition study on metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib  The rate of formation of N‚Äêdesmethyl imatinib (NDMI) from imatinib was evaluated in recombinant CYP3A4 (rCYP3A4) and human liver microsomes (HLM) at a concentration of 12.5 pmol CYP mL‚àí1 and 0.25 mg microsomal protein mL‚àí1, respectively.
label: Study

text: Azamulin (5 Œºmol L‚àí1) was added to the latter to specifically inactivate CYP3A4 enzyme (mechanism‚Äêbased inhibition, MBI).
label: Drug
Amount
Target

text: 34 This system was assumed to represent a CYP2C8 pathway since CYP enzymes other than CYP3A4 and CYP2C8 had a very minor contribution (3%) to imatinib metabolism.
label: Parameter

Parameter

text: 35 Incubation medium consisted of potassium phosphate buffer (0.1 mol L‚àí1, pH 7.4), either HLM with azamulin or rCYP3A4, DMSO (2%), NADPH (2 mmol L‚àí1) and milli Q water in a final volume of 200 ŒºL.

text: DMSO was used at a concentration that has a minimum impact on imatinib N‚Äêdemethylation (data not shown).
label: Extraction process
Drug

text: An extensive in vitro study showed that recombinant CYP2C8 enzyme (supersomes) was less sensitive than human liver microsomes (HLM) to identify potential mechanism‚Äêbased inhibitors and was characterised by a high lot‚Äêto‚Äêlot variability.
label: Study
Parameter
Parameter

text: Conversely, HLM are more reliable sources of CYP2C8 enzyme to evaluate mechanism‚Äêbased inhibition of the enzyme.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: 36 This is also likely to be the case for reversible inhibition of CYP2C8 enzyme.
label: Parameter

text: Therefore, CYP3A4‚Äêinactivated HLM was chosen to evaluate potential reversible inhibitions of CYP2C8‚Äêmediated metabolism of imatinib by Schisandra lignans.
label: Target
Parameter
Parameter
Drug
Herb name

text: Meanwhile, recombinant CYP3A4 enzyme was used to evaluate in vitro inhibitions of CYP3A4‚Äêmediated N‚Äêdemethylation of imatinib.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Drug

text: This was due to the lack of inhibitors capable of completely inhibiting CYP2C8 enzyme in HLM (gemfibrozil glucuronide inhibited the enzyme by up to 85%).
label: Target
Drug

text: 37 An overlap between CYP3A4 and CYP3A5 substrates has been recognised.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: However, the contribution of CYP3A5 for imatinib metabolism has been ruled out from thorough in vitro work 35 and clinical studies, including in a large number of patients genotyped for the CYP3A5 gene.
label: Parameter

text: 38 , 39  Although bosutinib has a high in vivo extraction ratio (EH), its intrinsic clearance in HLM was low (<20% reduction after a 60‚Äêmin incubation).
label: Drug

text: Thus, the CYP3A4‚Äêmediated formation of its main metabolite, N‚Äêdesmethyl bosutinib, also known as M5, 33 was followed instead.
label: Parameter

text: Incubation medium for this reaction was as described for NDMI formation, except that HLM (0.5 mg protein mL‚àí1) in a final volume of 100 ŒºL was used.
label: Drug

text: The formation rates of NDMI and M5 were determined over the concentration range of 5‚Äì100 Œºmol L‚àí1 for the respective parent compounds in the absence and presence of schisantherin A (0.1‚Äì25 Œºmol L‚àí1), schisandrin A and schisandrol B (0.5‚Äì25 Œºmol L‚àí1) without pre‚Äêincubation to evaluate their potential for reversible inhibition.

label: Drug

text: The inhibitory constants (k i) for a selective inhibitor of CYP enzymes are expected to be similar across different substrates of the enzyme only for purely competitive inhibitions.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: 40 This is, however, not generally the case due to the possibility of non‚Äêcompetitive and mixed inhibition.
41 Thus, specific k i values for Schisandra lignans on CYP‚Äêmediated metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib were determined in the current study.
label: Herb name
Parameter
Drug
Drug

text: The k i values were estimated using a nonlinear regression implemented in GraphPad Prism version 7.02 (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA, USA).
label: Parameter

text: The competitive, noncompetitive and mixed‚Äêinhibition models (Equations 1‚Äì3, respectively) were considered.
The best‚Äêfit equations for each of the ki estimations were selected based on visual inspections of model predictions versus experimental data and Akaike information criterion (AIC).

text: It is noteworthy that the reversible enzyme inactivation in the Simcyp Simulator is modelled solely by competitive inhibition.

Theoretically, the discrimination between competitive and noncompetitive inhibitions is not critical when concentrations of substrates are much lower than their K m values, which is often the case in the clinical setting.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: 41 , 42 Nevertheless, assigning the best‚Äêfit model is necessary for an accurate estimation of k i.  Nonspecific binding to microsomal membrane and CYP proteins may lead to an overestimation of k i values.
label: Parameter

text: Evaluations with a more intensive sampling time were performed for those showing significant depletion compared to control (one‚Äêway analysis of variance with Tukey post‚Äêhoc test, GraphPad Prism version 7.02).
Potential depletion of the inhibitors was modelled by first‚Äêorder kinetics as reported previously.
45 Corrections for k i values accounting for the concentrations of inhibitor at the end 45 , 46 and mid‚Äêtime of incubation 46 have been proposed, the latter of which was adopted for this study.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: PBPK models for Schisandra lignans  All population‚Äêbased PBPK modelling and simulations were conducted using the Simcyp Simulator (version 17 release 1, Certara UK Limited, Simcyp Division, Sheffield, UK) using the ‚Äòhealthy Chinese‚Äô and ‚Äògeneral North European Caucasian‚Äô population library data, which represent typical healthy adult people from the respective ancestry.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Ethnic group
Ethnic group
Pathology

text: The description of Simcyp Simulator workflow, basic algorithm and ordinary differential equations have been detailed previously.
47 , 48  The drug‚Äêrelated input parameters for Schisandra lignans are summarised in Table 1.
label: Herb name

text: The first‚Äêorder absorption model parameterised by the fraction of oral dose that enters the gut wall (f a), and the first‚Äêorder absorption rate constant (k a) was used for schisantherin A and schisandrol B, while a more sophisticated model, that is the compartmental absorption and transit (CAT) model was employed for schisandrin A.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name

text: A whole‚Äêbody PBPK model was used to describe the distribution of the three lignans.
label: Herb name

text: Drug partitioning to each of the tissue compartments was predicted in silico using the algorithms by Poulin and Theil (for schisandrin A and schisantherin A) 7 or Rodgers and Rowland (schisandrol B).
8 Partition coefficients (log P) of neutral compounds are generally the most influential parameter dictating the extent of distribution to different tissues.
label: Parameter

text: 8 , 49 A global sensitivity analysis suggested that uncertainties in tissue composition (that is concentrations of neutral lipids, neutral phospholipids, albumin and intracellular and extracellular water), but not tissue volumes may affect the in silico predictions of V ss of neutral compounds.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Parameter

text: Inter‚Äêcorrelation between tissue composition and log P also had a significant impact on the estimation of K p (tissue‚Äêto‚Äêplasma partition coefficients).
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: 49 For neutral compounds with a relatively small log P, e.g.
label: Parameter

text: schisantherin A, both prediction methods by Rodgers and Rowland 8 and Poulin and Theil 7 performed similarly.
label: Herb name

text: Therefore, the latter was selected for schisantherin A due to its simplicity.
label: Herb name

text: Interestingly, the Rodgers and Rowland algorithm provided a better estimate of K p of schisandrol B to different tissues, reflected by a better predictive performance of its pharmacokinetic profile compared to that of Poulin and Theil despite similar overall extent of distributions (V ss).
label: Parameter
Herb name
Parameter

text: However, the Rodgers and Rowland method tends to overestimate V ss and K p for highly lipophilic neutral compound, e.g.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: schisandrin A and thus the algorithm by Poulin and Theil is preferable for this lignan.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: The intrinsic clearance (CL int) of schisandrin A was obtained from re‚Äêanalysis of its depletion in HLM, while contribution of CYP3A enzymes (f m,CYP3A = 0.76) was estimated from the percent of inhibition by ketoconazole.
label: Parameter

text: 11 The mechanism‚Äêbased inhibition and induction of CYP3A4 following the chronic exposure to S. sphenanthera extract were modelled by an enzyme turnover model, depicted by an increase in degradation and synthesis of the active enzyme, respectively.
label: Parameter
Herb name

text: 48 , 50 The maximum fold of induction (Ind max) of schisandrin A was based on the fold‚Äêincrease of CYP3A4 mRNA in hepatocytes after exposure to S. sphenanthera extract (contains 2.7% of schisandrin A) 15 and was normalised to the difference of fold‚Äêinduction by rifampicin in this study compared to its standard value.
label: Parameter

label: Parameter

text: This was further corrected for the nonspecific binding during incubation (estimated fu inc of 0.4, Equation 4) assuming that 0.32 mg protein was present per million of hepatocytes (according to the hepatocellularity and content of microsomal protein per gram of liver 51 ).
label: Parameter

text: Since schisantherin A is also a major constituent of S. sphenanthera extract, 52 its induction parameters towards CYP3A enzymes were assumed to be the same as those for schisandrin A.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Parameter
Herb name

text: Induction of CYP3A4 enzyme is not analogous to a reversible inhibition due to a possibility for different binding sites on the enzyme (that is competitive, noncompetitive and mixed‚Äêinhibition) in the latter.
label: Target

text: This results in a high variability of inhibitory constants (k i) across different substrates, even for a selective CYP inhibitor, as has been observed with ketoconazole.
label: Parameter
Target
Drug

text: 40 Conversely, induction of CYP3A4 enzyme involves binding and stimulation of pregnane X receptor (PXR), a nuclear receptor that regulates the expression of CYP3A genes.
label: Target
Parameter

text: 53 This receptor binds to a variety of compounds (ligands) in a relatively nonspecific manner 54 and thus, the variability of in vitro induction parameters of CYP3A4 enzyme between structurally similar compounds is expected to be lower than that of reversible enzyme inhibition.
label: Parameter

text: PBPK simulations for Schisandra lignans were performed (10 virtual trials each) with trial designs (number of people, ethnicity, age range, proportion of male to female and dosing regimens) matched to the corresponding clinical studies (Table 2).
label: Herb name

Sex

label: Herb name

text: PBPK simulations were also carried out to evaluate the capability of PBPK models of Schisandra lignans in predicting the extent of interactions with midazolam and tacrolimus with trial designs as detailed in Table 3.

RESULTS 3.1.

Inhibition of in vitro metabolism of imatinib and bosutinib by Schisandra lignans  Inhibitions of metabolite formation from imatinib and bosutinib by Schisandra lignans mainly followed a competitive inhibition model as depicted in Figure 1.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name
Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: For model selection, the proposed models (competitive, noncompetitive and mixed‚Äêinhibitions) were fitted to the experimental data, and their goodness‚Äêof‚Äêfit based on AIC is summarised in Table S2.

The Dixon plot was used to estimate k i of schisandrol B towards CYP3A4 metabolism pathway of imatinib owing to a better fit to experimental data compared to the models detailed in Equations 1‚Äì3 (Figure 1C).
label: Parameter
Herb name
Parameter
Drug

text: Schisantherin A exhibited the strongest inhibitory activity towards CYP3A4‚Äêmediated metabolisms of imatinib and bosutinib (k i,u of 0.07 and 0.03 Œºmol L‚àí1, respectively).

PBPK models for Schisandra lignans  PBPK predictions of pharmacokinetics of schisandrin A, schisantherin A and schisandrol B following a single‚Äêdose administration of S. sphenanthera extract were similar to the clinically‚Äêobserved values (Figure 2, Table 2).
label: Herb name

label: Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: The clinically‚Äêobserved concentrations of both victim drugs all lay within the 5th to 95th percentiles of PBPK prediction (Figure 2).
label: Parameter

DISCUSSION  PBPK models of the three lignans in S. sphenanthera responsible for interactions with CYP3A substrates were successfully developed in this study.
label: Herb name
Parameter

text: The PBPK models have an excellent performance in predicting the interactions with midazolam 16 and tacrolimus 18 with Schisandra lignans as observed in the corresponding clinical studies.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name
Study

text: The verified models were then implemented to predict (a priori) the extent of interactions with imatinib and bosutinib.
label: Drug
Drug

text: It is noteworthy that S. sphenanthera is less commonly used in Western countries compared to Schisandra chinensis.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: 1 However, there is a paucity of clinical pharmacokinetic data for the latter.

Despite a substantial difference in major constituents for both Schisandra species, 52 the trend and extent of interactions with midazolam, a probe drug for CYP3A enzymes at an equivalent dose of the respective extracts, are likely to be similar.
label: Herb name
Drug
Parameter

text: 15  Although the PBPK models for schisandrin A and schisantherin A have been described before, 9 , 66 the evaluation of their capabilities in describing the clinically‚Äêobserved interactions with victim drugs is lacking.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: And, more importantly, PBPK predictions from these models were strictly limited to interactions with single isolated compounds and not as a combination of Schisandra lignans, the latter of which is more relevant in the clinical setting.
label: Herb name

text: Inhibition of tacrolimus metabolism by the combination of schisandrin A and schisantherin A was considerably overestimated using the previously reported models.
label: Drug
Herb name
Herb name

text: 9 This limitation was inherently circumvented by the incorporation of CYP3A induction 15 to the models as described in this study (Table 1).
label: Target

text: Upregulation of pregnane X receptor (PXR), which underlies the induction of CYP3A enzymes by constituents in the S. sphenanthera extract, has been highlighted in sandwich‚Äêcultured human hepatocytes and animal models, 2 , 15 , 67 although the predominant net outcome following a chronic exposure to the extract in clinical pharmacokinetic studies was CYP3A inhibition.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Target
Herb name
Study
Target

text: 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 In this complex interaction scenario (simultaneous reversible and mechanism‚Äêbased inhibitions and induction of CYP3A enzymes by multiple modulators), a PBPK modelling approach is best positioned to provide a more mechanistic prediction of the extent of interaction.
label: Target

text: 48 A comprehensive characterisation of metabolic pathways for each of the perpetrator compounds in S. sphenanthera extract 11 , 12 also enables auto‚Äêinhibition and potential interactions among Schisandra lignans to be accounted for in the PBPK models.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: However, a lack of clinical pharmacokinetic data following multiple‚Äêdosing regimens of S. sphenanthera extract limited further verification of the models at steady state.
label: Herb name

text: It is noteworthy that while clinical pharmacokinetic data for schisandrin A and schisantherin A were extracted from a study by Wei et al.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: 55 clinical data of schisandrol B were taken from another study.
label: Herb name

text: 56 This was necessary because concentration of schisandrol B in S. sphenanthera extract used in the former was questionably far lower than that normally found in commercially available extracts (0.01 55 vs 0.05‚Äì0.07% 56 , 61 ).
label: Parameter
Herb name
Herb name
Amount
Amount

text: This resulted in unrealistically high and low values of AUC and the corresponding apparent clearance (CL/F) of schisandrol B, respectively 55 and thus, clinical pharmacokinetic data from the study by Kim et al.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Herb name

text: 56 was used instead to verify the PBPK model of schisandrol B.
label: Herb name

text: Unfortunately, clinical data of both schisandrin A and schisantherin A were not reported in this study.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: The interactions between Schisandra lignans and both midazolam and tacrolimus in Chinese people were predicted with excellent accuracy (Figure 2, Table 3).
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug
Ethnic group

text: The simulation results implied that the PBPK model for tacrolimus, which was originally developed in European people, 57 could seamlessly be extrapolated to a Chinese population relying on the differences in body size, amount of CYP3A enzymes and frequency of CYP3A5 expression in the populations.
label: Drug
Ethnic group
Ethnic group
Parameter
Parameter

text: 68 Conversely, the elimination components for the default PBPK model of midazolam in the Simcyp Simulator had to be adjusted due to a far lower CL/F of midazolam in the associated clinical interaction study, compared to previously reported values.
label: Drug
Parameter
Drug
Study

text: 58 Despite this modification, the overall trend of interaction between Schisandra lignans and midazolam was well captured by the PBPK simulation, shown by similar ratios of AUC and C max compared to the clinically‚Äêreported parameter values (Table 3).
label: Herb name
Drug
Parameter
Parameter

text: S. sphenanthera was predicted to affect midazolam given intravenously to a lesser extent than that by oral administration (AUC ratios of 1.4 vs 2.0, respectively; simulations not shown), suggesting a more extensive inhibition of intestinal CYP3A compared to the corresponding enzymes in hepatocytes.
label: Herb name
Drug
Parameter
Amount
Amount
Target
Parameter

text: PBPK simulations highlighted that the recommended oral dosing regimen of schisantherin A, schisandrin A and schisandrol B increased the systemic exposure of imatinib by 30 to 40% after a single dose of the drug.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Parameter
Drug
Amount
Amount
Frequency

text: Conversely, it was predicted to have no effect on imatinib concentrations at steady state (Figure 4).
label: Drug
Parameter

text: This disparity was attributed to the mechanism‚Äêbased inactivation of CYP3A4 69 by a reactive metabolite of imatinib.
label: Target
Drug

text: 70 This leads to a lower sensitivity towards CYP3A inhibition at steady‚Äêstate, as demonstrated by a lack of clinically‚Äêsignificant interaction between imatinib and ritonavir.
label: Target
Drug
Drug

text: 71 Although steady‚Äêstate CL/F of imatinib is relatively susceptible to CYP3A induction, e.g.
label: Parameter
Drug
Target

text: by carbamazepine and phenytoin, 72 the predominant outcome from a chronic exposure to Schisandra lignans is a CYP3A inhibition and not induction.
label: Drug
Drug
Herb name
Target

text: 15 , 19 Inhibition of CYP2C8 enzyme by Schisandra lignans was evaluated given the importance of this enzyme on imatinib metabolism.
label: Target
Herb name
Drug
Parameter

text: 73 This, however, was predicted to have a minimum impact on steady‚Äêstate concentrations of imatinib, possibly due to a low EH of imatinib.
label: Parameter
Drug
Parameter
Drug

text: To our knowledge, this is the first study to highlight a reversible CYP2C8 inhibition by Schisandra lignans which may have clinical implications for other CYP2C8 substrates.
label: Target

text: Bosutinib is primarily metabolised by CYP3A4 enzyme with a contribution of this pathway (f m,CYP3A4) of approximately 0.9, estimated from a clinical interaction study with ketoconazole 74 based on the ratio of systemic exposure of bosutinib in the presence and absence of the CYP3A inhibitor.

text: 76 , 77 Bosutinib did not inhibit its own CYP3A4‚Äêmediated metabolism, 78 thus Schisandra lignans was expected to interact with bosutinib at single‚Äê (Figure 4) and multiple‚Äêdosing regimens (results not shown) to a similar extent.

text: Unlike imatinib, bosutinib has a high hepatic extraction ratio and its metabolism relies heavily on CYP3A4 enzyme.

text: 33 Therefore, it was unsurprising that bosutinib was predicted to be more affected by Schisandra lignans compared to imatinib (Figure 4).

CONCLUSIONS  PBPK models for the constituents of S. sphenanthera extract responsible for interactions were successfully developed and verified using existing clinical pharmacokinetic and herb‚Äìdrug interaction data with midazolam and tacrolimus.
